text: Aha, got it! New thing learned today, thanks Mo

text: I am considering testing Sportmonks API for live football data, does anyone here have experience with them? That is live info on goals, cards, penalties, VAR, etc. Any idea of the delay from an event happens until present in their API? Does it exist a mapping from Sportmonks team names to Betfair team names?

elements.text: I am considering testing Sportmonks API for live football data, does anyone here have experience with them? That is live info on goals, cards, penalties, VAR, etc. Any idea of the delay from an event happens until present in their API? Does it exist a mapping from Sportmonks team names to Betfair team names?

text:
I use them. Data quality is pretty good and they're super-responsive to corrections in their historic data.

I don't know what the delay is, but I would expect it to be somewhat variable depending on the speed of the feed the data analysts receive, how far ahead of the "live" broadcast they are receiving it, how much of the encoding is automated and how quickly specific analyst is able to encode the non-automated events. Overall however, I would expect it to be dwarfed by the impact of polling for new data.

I'm not aware of a mapping between Betfair team names and Sporting Monks. I've done that myself but found a fair number of inconsistencies in team names on the Betfair making, even in major competitions, rendering a mapping a bit problematic. My preference instead is to use fuzzy logic on the team names to find best matches. I've found that more reliable (i.e. less brittle).

elements.text:
I use them. Data quality is pretty good and they're super-responsive to corrections in their historic data.

I don't know what the delay is, but I would expect it to be somewhat variable depending on the speed of the feed the data analysts receive, how far ahead of the "live" broadcast they are receiving it, how much of the encoding is automated and how quickly specific analyst is able to encode the non-automated events. Overall however, I would expect it to be dwarfed by the impact of polling for new data.

I'm not aware of a mapping between Betfair team names and Sporting Monks. I've done that myself but found a fair number of inconsistencies in team names on the Betfair making, even in major competitions, rendering a mapping a bit problematic. My preference instead is to use fuzzy logic on the team names to find best matches. I've found that more reliable (i.e. less brittle).

text: Isn't it better to map IDs?

elements.text: Isn't it better to map IDs?

text: For the price it’s quite incredible. But, I would say that in the age of exclusivity they will surely run into data rights issues - especially with the top leagues.

elements.text: For the price it’s quite incredible. But, I would say that in the age of exclusivity they will surely run into data rights issues - especially with the top leagues.

text: I wouldn’t be surprised to hear they are reselling official feeds with latency which renders it useless for bet placement

elements.text: I wouldn’t be surprised to hear they are reselling official feeds with latency which renders it useless for bet placement

text: That's actually what I do, but via the team names and on-the-fly, rather than relying on a "definitive" mapping.

elements.text: That's actually what I do, but via the team names and on-the-fly, rather than relying on a "definitive" mapping.

text: I'm a bit surprised you don't maintain that definitive mapping. I'm interested because I'm currently building such a mapping for a different third party

elements.text: I'm a bit surprised you don't maintain that definitive mapping. I'm interested because I'm currently building such a mapping for a different third party

text:
I used to, but the introduction of previously unseen teams, especially in cup competitions meant that I also needed an automated way to match teams not in the mapping, but I also found that variances in name, especially at the Betfair end meant that the expectations of the mapping could get in the way.

On the other hand using fuzzy logic text matching between a Betfair list and a SportMonks list was pretty bullet proof and it was easier to use this for all matches rather than just as a fallback. Especially since I use it with a data scraped from other sources too.

elements.text:
I used to, but the introduction of previously unseen teams, especially in cup competitions meant that I also needed an automated way to match teams not in the mapping, but I also found that variances in name, especially at the Betfair end meant that the expectations of the mapping could get in the way.

On the other hand using fuzzy logic text matching between a Betfair list and a SportMonks list was pretty bullet proof and it was easier to use this for all matches rather than just as a fallback. Especially since I use it with a data scraped from other sources too.

text: I think the main problem of sportmonks is that it's not a streaming API, you need to poll. You can poll, say, twice a second, but it's still going to be a pull interface rather than push.

elements.text: I think the main problem of sportmonks is that it's not a streaming API, you need to poll. You can poll, say, twice a second, but it's still going to be a pull interface rather than push.

text: Otherwise, yeah, they are responsive and very good.

elements.text: Otherwise, yeah, they are responsive and very good.

text: OTOH it's very very rare that one mapped id pair changes its meaning, in my experience

elements.text: OTOH it's very very rare that one mapped id pair changes its meaning, in my experience

text: and it's good when they rename teams, so that you don't need to wait for both DBs to be updated :wink:

elements.text: and it's good when they rename teams, so that you don't need to wait for both DBs to be updated

text: Yep. If you find something similarly cheap and faster, please do tell ;-)

text:
<http://www.betsapi.com|www.betsapi.com>
<http://www.totalcorner.com|www.totalcorner.com>

The former is generally good. The latter is prone to blackouts for a few days every now and then.

Neither do streaming as far as I know.
